Old and Confused Dev
text:
hey HN! I'll be 35 in 2 months, recently became a dad and am a little confused about what's next in terms of my career.

My background: having no formal education I started out working in classic IT (fixing Windows related errors on client laptopts) for 6 years. Picked up programming & started tinkering with linux as a hobby, which led me to become a sysadmin/devops for 5 years. Eventually I became a backend developer mostly working in GO. My company had a merger, new teams were created and for the last year my title has been ML engineer. I even started tech leading this year. My company loves me, they're telling me regularly.

But I feel like all I'm doing is gluing together AWS services, and even though I'm busy I don't feel like I'm being challenged. Because of that about 3 months ago I started studying in my free time. As I said I have no formal education, so things like system design are all new to me. I'm going through the MIT 6.824: Distributed Systems course which is a blast! I also started learning Rust and learning about low level stuff, and wrote a couple CLI apps. Also spent time strengthening my DS & algo skills.

I don't have a clear idea though where to go next, and based on my study list you can tell I'm a bit all over the place. Learning about all these new things got me super excited though. I have this voice inside me that says I should specialize in a particular domain & the tech around it. And I need to do it NOW since I'm considered "old" as a dev. I'm also embarrassed that it took me this long to get to the point where I'm at. My questions: - is it reasonable to specialize in something like distributed systems, or all most of the problems solved at this point? - If I decide to go the route of systems programming, would companies even consider me with my background? Like I write python during the day, but will they care that I dedicate all my free time to other techs/languages?

Show HN: ger2err: turn Gerrit comments into compiler errors
text:
Did you know that the coworkers who review yuor code are actually compilers in disguise?

ger2err takes a commit ID as an argument, and spits out their review comments in the style of GCC.

You can feed this to your favorite editor so that you can easily navigate to the indicated lines of code, and address everything, just like if the diagnostics had come from a compilation job.
